results.notes:
Cap: Orange fading to yellow orange towards the margin, flesh of the cap is organish-white and the gills are light orange. Gills are moist when fresh and young, and are densely packed. Gills are adnexed to the stipe and are serrated. Striations visible on the margin and go about halfway on the top of cap.
Stipe: long, striped (concentric zones of shaggyness as in the words of Michael Kuo), total length of stipe is 15cm, with the diameter starting off 1.5cm at the bottom thinning to 1.1cm at the apex. Volval sac present and intact, but adhering to the stipe. Inside of stipe more hollow but packed with a soft white pith. Anulus still present and was partially attached to gills/margin when picked from its location.
Spores: All white spore print, sub-globose or elliptical, greenish tint when not stained (possibly due to light refraction), approx. 6.6 micrometers in length (no precise measurement could be made so the range is between 5.6 and 7.8 micrometers and the specimen was not fully mature).

Odor: pleasant, earthy, buttery
Flavor: mild

results.notes:
Habitat: Found in gravel nearby mixed duff and leaves. Grows under or near hardwoods; most likely saprobic. Almost always isolated from others and takes 3-8 days to fully grow to maturity. Only comes after medium rain, never after heavy flooding. The conditions usually range from 45%-76% humidity, and when the heat is between 65-89⁰F.
Cap: umbonate to flat, starts off egg shaped/ball shaped when young. The hymenium is free and has roughly a centimeter or less of space between the gills and stipe. Gills are greyish whitish and are closely packed, possibly serrated (variable sizes of gills). Cap is wrapped in a snakeskin like covering, with soft but fibrous scaly tissue. The diameter of the fully mature cap was 13.5 cm.
Stipe: height of 23cm and a diameter ranging from 1cm to 1.3cm at most (thickness of bottom where the mycelium lies is greater than the stipe). The young specimen has a free anulus that can move up and down the stem, but the mature specimen seemed to have an intact but thin anulus compared to Macrolepiota procera.
Flesh: Flesh is mostly white and doesnt change immediately on cutting or breaking, but over time turns a tinge of pinkish whitish. Stipe is partially hollow with think pithy tissue that is lightly packed.
Spores: Spore print is white when thin, but over time clumps into thick pinkish-brownish prints. However, it is still overall mostly white. The average length of a spore is 14.25 micrometers and the width is about 6.25 micrometers, leaving a ratio of about 2.2. The spores are not globose nor subglobose and are ellipsoidal. They have smooth and thick walls and appear to have a small pore at one of thr polar ends of the spore.
Microscope Specs: WF20x/10mm eyepiece with a 100x oil phase objective lense. The FOV has been calibrated/measured to be 100 micrometers at 2000x magnification.

results.notes: Large Amanita in section Vaginatae. Cap diameter about 9cm, stem about 18 cm. Macroscopic features appear consistent with description of Amanita cacaina Tulloss nom. prov., allowing for the greater maturity of this specimen. See http://amanitaceae.org/?Amanita%20cacaina. The few recorded collections of this Amanita have been in the southern Appalachians.

results.notes: Collected this specimen of P. sclerotiorum within a small area of mixed woods next to a lake. This is precisely the same site of my first collections last season in this area that were positively identified by DNA sequencing thanks to Drs. I.G. Safonov and Linas Kudzma (see obs 418409, 418412, and 419545). This collection appears to be the same, though more robust and weathered than previous specimens which were collected a bit earlier in the season. As with previous samples, while pore surfaces blue quickly, internal flesh shows only very minor bluing with damage.

results.notes: A single fruiting body brought in by an unknown NJMA foray participant. I only saw it when the stipe was already discolored dark gray/brownish-gray. John B and I together keyed it out to rubescens and rubriceps. The latter could be a better fit because the cuticle peels to about 1/3. I didn’t see this russula staining red before the changeover to gray. John took it home to work in it some more. More details, like spore measurements, tbd.

results.location_name: Hamilton Co., Tennessee, USA

results.notes:
Datos de Yopal, registrado en Bosque Seco Tropical (temporada de lluvia). Precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, Precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio. con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas. (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017).

Son comunes plantas representativas como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

Hongos de Colombia (Bogotá, 2019):
https://www.researchgate.net/...

Son comunes plantas representativas como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

results.notes:
Datos de Yopal, registrado en Bosque Seco Tropical (temporada de lluvia). Precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, Precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio. con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. results.notes: Second specimen of P. sclerotiorum within a small area of mixed woods next to a lake. This example appeared to be growing from well-rotted wood. This is precisely the same site of my first collections last season in this area that were positively identified by DNA sequencing thanks to Drs. I.G. Safonov and Linas Kudzma (see obs 418409, 418412, and 419545). This collection appears to be the same, though more robust and weathered than previous specimens which were collected a bit earlier in the season. As with previous samples, while pore surfaces blue quickly, internal flesh shows only very minor bluing with damage.

Must have fruited last night as they were not there yesterday.I know I’m new at this, but these seem to have every feature of Psilocybe cyanescens, no? results.notes:
Russula compactae/brevipes group.
Odor: intensely fishy/rotten fish.
Taste: extremely acrid/hot.
Fruiting beneath Western hemlock(Tsuga heterophylla).
Cap: 4 to 6.5cm wide,dull White=staining brown. No separable cap cuticle. Matte finish.
Gills: yellowish/white staining brown immediately where handled. Dark brown within 2hrs.
Sub-gills present.
Stem: 3-4cm long. Staining readily brown. Dark brown later. Slender. Far more slender/long than Russula cascadensis.
Spore printed a single cap on a glass slide for microscopy.
Spore print: dull white.
Spores: round, subglobose. Ornamented with warts/spines.
Harvested 3 specimens and dehydrated for home herbarium collection.

Growing with oak and hickory. Very faint odor, basically indistinct. Conditions were very dry, so perhaps the odor was faded. Bruised blue very slowly—the last picture shows blue bruising after about 10 minutes. Clear, almost prominent, reticulation on stipe. The pore layer is quite tall.

The smaller one was growing from the same base. The stipe on that one was pure yellow.
